review.title: Social Media-based Substance Use Prediction
review.abstract: In this paper, we demonstrate how the state-of-the-art machine learning and text mining techniques can be used to build effective social media-based substance use detection systems. Since a substance use ground truth is difficult to obtain on a large scale, to maximize system performance, we explore different feature learning methods to take advantage of a large amount of unsupervised social media data. We also demonstrate the benefit of using multi-view unsupervised feature learning to combine heterogeneous user information such as Facebook `"likes" and "status updates" to enhance system performance. Based on our evaluation, our best models achieved 86% AUC for predicting tobacco use, 81% for alcohol use and 84% for drug use, all of which significantly outperformed existing methods. Our investigation has also uncovered interesting relations between a user's social media behavior (e.g., word usage) and substance use.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: "Substance use disorder (SUD) is defined as a condition in which the repeated use of substances such as alcohol, drugs and tobacco causes clinically and functionally significant impairments in an individual's daily life (SAMHSA, 2015). According to the 2014 National Study on Drug Use and Health, one in ten Americans 12 years and older had substance use disorder. Substance use also costs Americans more than $700 billion a year in increased health costs, crime and lost productivity (NIDA, 2015). Nowadays, people also spend a lot of time on social media such as Twitter, Facebook and Instagram to interact with friends and family, share ideas and thoughts, provide status updates, and organize events and activities. The pervasive and widespread use of social media underscores the need to investigate its intersection with substance use and its potential as a scalable and cost-effective solution for screening and preventing substance abuse and abuse.

sections.heading: 8 Discussion and Future Work
sections.text: Similarly, the MUE-based monitored prediction used only the intersection of all three sets of data, which is very small (only 896 users), so it would be useful if a future multiview learning algorithm were able to use all the available data (e.g., merging all monitored and unmonitored training data). Furthermore, our best SPE model only has 50 dimensions, while our best SLE model has 300 dimensions. This could be because the monitored training data used by SPE is almost three times smaller than that used by SLE. Surprisingly, however, SPE-based models performed better than SLE-based models. We expect that with more training data, the performance of SPE-based methods can be further improved.

sections.heading: 9 Conclusion
sections.text: We believe that social media is a promising platform both for studying SUD-related human behaviors and for engaging the public in the prevention and early detection of substance abuse. In this study, we focused on four main tasks: (1) the use of unattended functions that learn to use a large amount of unattended social media user data (2) the use of multiview feature learning to combine heterogeneous user information such as "like" and "status updates" to learn comprehensive user representation (3) the construction of SUD prediction models based on learned user functions (4), and the use of correlation analyses to achieve results that can be interpreted humanly.
